body:
What if a RouteParser reference was added to Route instances? Then you could do:

```php
$userUri = $route->getRouteParser()->relativeUrlFor('users', ['id' => $user->id()]);
```
What is wrong with adding it into the DI. If the route callable needs the route parser, then that should be injected into the callable. Or am I missing anything?

@adriansuter because this functionality should be easily accessible since a lot of users will be using it. Users shouldn’t have to map internal functionality externally via DI to access it. You should be able to do everything without depending on DI.
I see. So, it needs to be added to the request, needn't it? Either directly or via route, as @shadowhand suggested. Otherwise the signature of the route callable would be changed, right?

The route parser can be injected into the route callable without DI. Either the user writes a class and passes the route parser to the constructor, or in case of a closure, the user could do `function(...) use ($routeParser) {}` and use it.
I’m thinking that we may be able to add it via the `RoutingMiddleware` where we append the `route` attribute already and the `routingResults` attribute as well.

Sure.

That's some sort of compromise. That way, the request object serves as some sort of "internal container". Of course, at least to me, it still feels weird to have the route parser in the request.

Yes I agree. It would be nice to pass a context object in the route, or some sort of way to access context bound functionality. Using the request is hackish, and it's not typed which is annoying. You're just hoping it will be available.

We need to figure out a different mechanism for this.

No idea so far.

But to be able to type-hint, we could define a class with static methods that would return the type-hinted attributes.

Something like
`RequestUtils::getRouteParser($request)`.

Not the best solution, I know. We still assume that the attributes are there.

I am supporting that idea.

Probably, to make things even easier for a user, we could add other static methods to retrieve the route parser directly.

Or even a mapping of `relativeUrlFor`, although in this case, the name `RequestAttributes` would not make sense anymore.

Right, I am suggesting having a single attribute that holds all references to Slim objects, rather than defining multiple attributes in the request. It makes it easier to document and reduces the chances that a 3rd party middleware will overwrite something.

The naming is arbitrary, I could see something like:

```php
$userUri = SlimContext::fromRequest($request)->relativeUriFor('users', ['id' => $id]);
```
Why don't we do `RouteContext` since all those attributes would pertain to the route itself?

Would it be possible, that someone needs the callable resolver in route callable? Because if yes, then this should maybe also be packed into this new context object.

What about the response factory? Maybe someone needs that in the callable.

I think that maybe we could have two different context objects instead. One which is created by the AppFactory or on Instantiation of the app and can be accessed statically and then a route context object which needs to be instantiated from within the route.

`AppContext` would reference the latest instantiation of the app. I don't see why people would instantiate multiple apps anyway.

```php
$responseFactory = AppContext::getResponseFactory()
$callableResolver = AppContext::getCallableResolver()
```

```php
$routeContext = RouteContext::fromRequest($request);
```

I don't think that response factory and callable resolver fit, because they are almost always consistent objects, whereas the route changes state depending on the request. Context should be used for variable things and the DIC should be used for consistent things.

Put another way, the `ResponseFactory` (and `CallableResolver`) should be injected into the `AppFactory` from the DIC and is therefore already available to any middleware or handler that needs it.
Agree, but if you do not have a DI container, how do you access to these instances?

@shadowhand that still doesn't solve the problem. All you need to do right now is `$app->getRouteCollector()->getRouteParser()` but it's still not accessible from inside of a route callable.

We need a `RouteContext` object for sure. as for the `CallableResolver` and the `ResponseFactory` we can solve that in a different issue perhaps.

Great.

We cannot remove or change the attributes `route` and `routingResults` added to the request, can we? That is a BC.

We will need those if we use something like `RouteContext::fromRequest($request)` as it will pull the data from those attributes.

I envision the `RouteContext` object having the following interface:
```php
class RouteContext {
    public function getRoute(): RouteInterface
    public function getRouteParser(): RouteParserInterface
    public function getRoutingResults(): RoutingResults
    public static function fromRequest(ServerRequestInterface $request): RouteContext
}
```

I was asking because @shadowhand  suggested to add the `RouteContext` only. So instead of having three or more attributes attached to the route, only one would be attached, the `RouteContext`. The route, the route parser and the routing results would then be added to and can be retrieved from the `RouteContext`.

But as we cannot remove these two attributes, maybe it is better to follow your idea.
